summary: This is a memorandum from a forensic psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center summarizing psychological contacts with inmate Jeffrey Epstein from his arrival on July 8, 2019, through August 8, 2019. It details his placement on and off suicide watch, his psychological assessments, his reported incidents including a neck injury, and his interactions with staff and his legal team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the psychological memo, detailing his mental state, suicide risk assessments, and incidents while incarcerated at MCC New York.

persons.name: Chief Psychologist
persons.context: Spoke with Central Office on July 8, 2019, and was involved in the initial decision to place Epstein on suicide watch.

persons.name: Operations Lieutenant
persons.context: Contacted the on-call psychologist at approximately 2am on July 23, 2019, to report Epstein was being placed on suicide watch after being found with a string around his neck.

connections.description: The Chief Psychologist was involved in the initial clinical decision-making regarding Epstein's suicide risk upon his arrival.
The Operations Lieutenant reported the July 23 incident involving Epstein to the on-call psychologist, leading to his placement on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein's Intake and Initial Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at MCC New York and underwent an intake screening. The Chief Psychologist consulted with Central Office, and it was determined he should be placed on suicide watch due to increased risk factors.

events.title: First Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Epstein was assessed for suicide risk. He denied any suicidal ideation, intention, or plan. His protective factors were deemed to outweigh his risk factors, and he was removed from suicide watch and placed on psychology observation.

events.title: Neck Injury Incident
events.description: At approximately 2am, Epstein was found with a string hanging around his neck. He was placed on suicide watch. During assessment, he claimed not to remember the event and later told staff his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Court Note on Suicidal Tendencies
events.description: Epstein returned from court with a note from the court indicating 'suicidal tendencies.' He was assessed again but denied being suicidal. He also reported seeing the DHO about his neck injury incident report, which was expunged.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a string around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch. He later told staff his cellmate tried to kill him.
Epstein repeatedly denied suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during multiple psychological assessments, citing his desire to fight his case and that suicide was against his religion.
A note from the court on August 1, 2019, indicated Epstein had 'suicidal tendencies,' but a subsequent prison assessment concluded his protective factors outweighed his risk factors.
Epstein reported that an incident report regarding his neck injuries was expunged after he saw the DHO (Discipline Hearing Officer).
The memo documents Epstein's repeated requests to be moved to general population and his complaints about conditions in SHU, including noise and lack of a spoon.
